dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The end of Winter.  SNOW blankets the landscape.  A SMALL STREAM rushes through the VALLEY.  A clear, blue sky hang the DISTANT MOUNTAINS adding to the beauty of the setting

dialogues.speaker: SUPER IMPOSE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA begins to PAN.  The color of the SNOW begins t change, darkening from PURE WHITE to ASH GRAY, eventually COAL BLACK.  We continue to pan until we arrive at..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plague.  Once a charming settlement it is now ravaged by disease.  Everywhere BONFIRES burn, sending plumes of BLA SMOKE rising into the sky -- the ash and soot drift back blackening the earth.  VILLAGERS scurry about in tattered clothing, their faces soiled by soot as they throw object WOOD and CLOTH into the fires. THREE HORSEMEN ride into the village.  Two of them we can clearly as large, powerful men with savage faces.  The TH MAN'S man's face is hidden from us in the shadows of a bl HOODED CAPE.  He dismounts, motioning for the other two t for him. The Hooded Man walks though the village.  The SOUND of HAMMERING fills the air as several VILLAGERS finish build make-shift GALLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Built of stone it is already centuries old.  A VILLAGER s guard at the entrance.  The Hooded Man approaches and WHI something in the Villagers ear, then holds up a GOLD PIEC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and musty, lit only by shafts of LIGHT which flow in through the windows.  The Hooded Man follows the Villager across the stone floor until he reaches a WOODEN DOOR at back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No windows.  The Hooded Man enters.  In the center of the a CIRCLE has been drawn.  Bordering the circle are hundre CANDLES, forming a ring of fire.  A MAN stands in the cen his head bowed -- his weight supported by thick ROPES aro his wrists that are fastened to a wooden beam which runs length of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vieira... VIEIRA looks up.  He is old, his hair thin and gray, but eyes are alive, defiant.  The Hooded Man moves closer.  V follows him with his eyes, trying to see the Hooded Man's Vieira strains against his ropes.  The Hooded Man does no move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How comes it your are not afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would'st you harm one who comes to aid you? Vieira's silence indicates he is listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've come to strike a bargain with you.  I wish to learn the power of changing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what would'st I gain from this bargain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalantly) Your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? The Hooded Man slowly pulls back his hood.  We see his fa the first time.  It is hard, brutal, his eyes cold and da He grins -- a wicked grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a magic of my own. The Hooded Man removes a KNIFE from under his coat.  He h it before Vieira, then he quickly stabs it into his chest face fills with pain -- blood flows from the wound -- he to his knees.  A beat.  He slowly looks up at Vieira as h pulls the knife from his chest, then stands unharmed.  Vi cannot believe what he has seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teach me the chant and I will take your place on the gallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP of RELIGIOUS-LOOKING MEN walk toward the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vieira has finished teaching the chant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you recite the chant you must concentrate of the form you wish to take.  The stonger you are the longer you can hold the illusion. In the b.g. we HEAR the SOUND of FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs.  Vieira looks at the Hooded Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come.  Quickly, take my place. The Men enter.  One of them looks at the Hooded Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? The Hooded Man stares at him -- a hard, unnerving stare - slowly, his thin lips from a cruel grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just saying goodbye to an old friend. Vieira stares at the Hooded Man angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a bargain.  You promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lied. The Hooded Man walks from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hooded Man walks out.  The TWO HORSEMEN ride up.  The Hooded Man climbs on his horse.  He takes a DEEP BREATH a looks at a RANGE OF MOUNTAINS in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of SWORDS CROSSING fill the air.  Two MEN, one the other OLD fight across the SNOW-SWEPT GROUND.  In. th a large, stone building is built at the base of a mountai range. The Young Man fights furiously, his only weapon strength, he is clearly inexperienced.  The OLD MAN is agile, and e moves out of the way of each blow.  The Young Man swings wildly, he loses his balance.  The Old Man strikes his SW away, then pushes him to the ground.  The Young Man looks the older man raises his SWORD above his head.  Their eye lock.  The Old Man smiles and slowly lowers the sword to Young Man's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over. The Old Man reaches out his hand, helping the Young Man t feet.  The Young Man is clearly angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your anger blinds you.  You must learn to control it.  When the time comes you'll only have but one chance.  You best use it well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large and barren.  A fires roars in the fireplace.  The O sits across a wooden table from the Young man as they fin eating. The Young Man appears restless.  He pushes his plate away -- stands up and walks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the village for some ale -- and if the truth be known, I need to see someones face other than yours, old man. They smile.  The Young Man takes his SWORD then puts on h COAT.  He picks up a SACK and leaves.  The Old Man begins clear away the dishes.  Suddenly he stops -- his smile fa He looks towards the door filled with a premonition.  Out we HEAR the SOUND of SWORDS CROSSING.  It lasts only for moment.  SILENCE. A blinding GREEN LIGHT fills the frame of the door.  The begins to TREMBLE -- the STONES of the building shake fro force -- debris falls from the ceiling.  It stops.  SILEN The Old Man takes his SWORD from the mantle.  The DOOR OP The SOUND of the WIND rushes in.  Outside nothing can be - only the darkness of the night.  A beat.  The Young Man enters the room.  The Old Man smiles at the sight of him. Young Man places his sack on the table. The Old Man turns his back as he starts to replace his sw the mantle.  The Young Man's expression hardens.  He star the Old Man's neck as he starts to raise his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a SILVER WINE CHALICE he sees the reflection of the YO MAN who is now slowly raising his SWORD and about to stri the Old Man's neck. In one fluid movement the Old Man unsheathes his sword, t turns quickly.  The Young Man's blade slices through the missing it's target.  The Old Man pivots and slices his b across the Young Man's chest.  The Young Man winces in pa then takes a deep breath -- his body begins to shake viol A TRANSFORMATION BEGINS.  The image of Young Man begins t and is replaced by the HOODED MAN.  He LAUGHS LOUDLY as h holds up his arms as if prompting The Old Man for his appreciation of the illusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hatefully) Kilvara... The Hooded Man smiles when he hears his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It flatters me you remember, old one. It's been what... two hundred years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not been long enough.  What witchcraft is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive -- is it not?  The problem is I can only keep the illusion for a few minutes.  I need more power to hold the form longer.  I need the Highlander.  Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know -- and even if I did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) I know.  I know-- you would not tell me.  Loyalty -- it really is a concept that eludes me. (shrugs his shoulders) Oh well -- I shall find him.  Time is on my side. The Old Man looks sadly at the open door.  Kilvara notice grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what you're looking for? Kilvara opens the SACK.  Inside it is the head of the You Man.  Kilvara LAUGHS, a deep guttural laugh.  He turns an starts towards the door.  Suddenly he stops and turns bac face the Old Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mockingly) Oh -- I almost forgot.  Your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does not come off as easily as the young ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Perhaps -- but it comes off none the less. With a savage YELL Kilvara draws his sword and lunges at Old Man.  The Old Man steps aside and Kilvara's sword sma down on the table, shattering it into splinters. The two Horsemen step into the room and watch.  Kilvara l again -- and again -- each time the Old Man side-steps hi Kilvara swings -- the Old Man ducks -- the blade hits the wall -- SPARKS FLY -- ROCK EXPLODES.  The Old Man slices blade across Kilvara chest.  A deep gash is cut -- blood Kilvara examines the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dead. With brutal strength Kilvara begins his attack again, whi his sword through the air furiously.  Their swords cross sparks fly.  Kilvara is too powerful for the Old Man.  Al can do is back up -- using his sword to block each feroci blow.  They pass through a large ARCH at the rear of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is built at the mouth of a vast CAVE.  TORCH in the walls of the cavern are the only source of light. WOODEN BRIDGE is built over a deep RAVINE.  Kilvara and t Man continue their fight across the bridge.  The Horsemen behind, enjoying the battle.  The Old Man's strength is g way under the merciless attack. The SPARKS from each contact is even more dazzling in the light of the cavern.  Kilvara swings again.  The Old Man to block it.  In one fluid movement Kilvara scrapes his S along the Old Man's -- then lunges forward -- thrusting h blade through the Old Man's chest.  The Old Man SCREAMS i pain.  Kilvara lifts him up with the blade.  Kilvara flin off the blade and onto the ground.  The Old Man is on his knees.  Kilvara raises his sword above his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There can be only one. Kilvara brings the blade down.  It slices through the Old neck, severing his head from his body.  Kilvara waits, preparing himself.  A stream of bright GREEN LIGHT begins flow from the BODY of the OLD MAN.  It grows BRIGHTER and BRIGHTER.  The Body of the old man begins to hover above ground, then in a pulsing burst of energy the LIGHT flows Kilvara.  The force knocks him to his knees. The GROUND SHAKES -- The walls of the cavern move.  Sudde chunks of rock are blown out of the walls -- the RUMBLING grows LOUDER and LOUDER -- blinding GREEN LIGHT FILLS the and then -- a deafening EXPLOSION.  Whole sections of the cavern begin to collapse -- covering the exit -- trapping everyone inside.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The RUMBLING SOUND subsides.  In the distance we hear the savage SCREAM of Kilvara.  The CAMERA MOVES UP the side o mountain.  As we come over the top we see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The familiar towers of the city skyline stand along the b their LIGHTS reflecting off the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thick FOG hangs in the air.  A light wind blows, moving newspapers and other articles of trash along the deserted street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crates and trash dumpsters line the alley.  A single, nak light bulb shines down like a spotlight.  Through the fog SILHOUETTE of man appears as he steps under the light.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: We follow the man from behind.  He is tall, dressed in a tan rain-coat, jeans and sneakers.  A small TRAVEL BAG is over his shoulder.  As he moves down the alley he hears a SCRAPING SOUND.  HE stops -- but does not turn around. A street PUNK emerges from behind a trash crate, scraping BLADE of his KNIFE along the wall of a building.  He stud the man for a moment as he runs his thumb along the edge blade, almost caressing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'cha got in the bag? Not only does the man not answer -- he doesn't even turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- you hear me? CONNER MACLEOD slowly turns around.  He is mid thirties, handsome, his chin dotted with the stubble of a beard.  H calm, detached -- yet under the surface there is a great sadness from a lifetime of pain and loneliness.  He stare the Punk wearily -- knowing both what is going to happen what the outcome will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Yes -- I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Now, give it up. Macleod studies the Punk for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home -- while you still can. Macleod turns his back to him and starts to walk away.  T Punk moves after him quickly.  Macleod reaches into a tra and pulls out a piece of PIPE.  The Punk stops and stares Macleod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) What do you think you're gonna to do with that? Macleod raises the pipe, twirling it around expertly in h hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadly calm) Let's find out. A beat.  The Punk is losing confidence.  He looks at Macl

dialogues.speaker: MACLEOD'S EYES
dialogues.text: Deep.  Confidant.  They radiate an intensity that seems t into the Punk. The Punk is unnerved by Macleod's calm.  Macleod waits, l him make the next move.  A beat.  The Punk backs away and disappears into the darkness.  Macleod stares him for a m then drops the pipe to the ground and walks off in the ot direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod stops at the mouth of the alley where it intersec with the street.  He stares across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old building.  A sign reads:  RUSSELL NASH, ANTIQUES. A sadness falls across his face -- his mind floods with memories as he looks at the building. Across the street the door of the antique store opens.  R an attractive woman in her fifties exits -- locks the doo walks down the street. Macleod watches her affectionately -- painfully.  As she crosses the street, he steps back into the shadows of the alley, hiding in the darkness.  Rachel reaches the alley, stops -- thinks -- looks back at the Antique Store.  She only a few feet away from Macleod.

dialogues.speaker: MACLEOD
dialogues.text: Macleod struggles to make a decision.  Slowly he raises h hand -- reaches out -- but cannot bring himself to touch Rachel starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel. No more needs to be said.  She recognizes the voice insta She turns around slowly and looks behind her.  In the b.g Macleod steps out of the darkness.  He smiles at her weak Confusion fills her face, but is quickly replaced by a wa emotion.  She moves towards Macleod slowly, as if trying determine if he is really there.  She cups her hands to h face and stares deeply into his eyes.  No words are spoke none need to be.  The power of their feelings are shown i their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded with tables, chairs, cabinets and other rare old objects of furniture.  Macleod is seated at a 17th centur dinning table.  Rachel stands in the center of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it's not safe here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police still have a lot of questions for Russell Nash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take care of myself. Rachel's emotion builds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here, Conner?  After seven years without a word, why have you come back?  You went off to make a new life with Brenda and that was the last I heard-- A sadness falls over Macleod's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenda's dead. Rachel is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Four years ago.  I've nowhere else to go.  You're all I have, Rachel -- and I'm just so tired of being alone. His words touch her.  She opens a cabinet and pulls out a bottle of GLENMORGANGIE scotch.  Macleod forces a weak sm In the light he looks tired.  She pours him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't over, is it, Conner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Rachel's face fills with compassion.  She reaches out and Macleod.  He lays his head on her shoulder like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every inch of wall-space is filled with shelves and BOOKS Macleod walks along a row studying the titles.  A faint g falls across his face as he sees a selected works of poet Rachel enters the room with a tea service and places it o table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything else you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm fine.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you've come home, Conner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. Rachel leaves.  Macleod takes a small book off the shelf looks through it.  Outside a STREAK of LIGHTNING cuts acr the night sky.  Macleod looks out the window concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeenth century Scotland.  The CAMERA rise over an ol stone wall.  A charming farm house with stone walls and a thatched roof sits in the distance.  Smoke drifts lazily the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man toils behind an ox, his arms straining as he guides plow through the soft earth.  He stops, runs his hand acr his brow, then turns around.  It is Macleod.  His hair is longer, but he looks exactly the same. The FARMER and owner of the land, a kindly-looking man in fifties walks over to him.  He picks up and handful of so tastes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be a good harvest this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you really tell from doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you just like to eat dirt. They both LAUGH.  SARAH, fifteen years old, with flaxen h and bright blue eyes approaches Macleod with a water pale

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) Would you care for some water, Conner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye -- that I would, lass. Conner takes the ladle and pours it over his head.  He sc out some more water and drinks, then WINKS at Sarah.  She blushes and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think my Sarah fancies you, Conner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a treasure she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll soon be of age. Macleod understands him only too well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your words are kind and they flatter me -- but I think of her as a sister. Besides, you hardly know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that for six months you've worked hard and asked for little. That you're a good and honest man. What more need I know? The conversation is interrupted by the SOUND of HORSES HO thundering across the fields.  TWO MEN, dirty and rough-l ride up to the house.  They have the look of warriors to The Farmers wife and Sarah stand outside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Farmer arrives, out of breath from his run across the field.  In the b.g. we see Macleod going into the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day. The Men do not answer.  The Farmer is nervous.  He has se like this before.  A few other FARM HANDS, mostly OLD MEN WOMEN come in from the fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are welcome to share our food and our fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do not share, old man.  We take. Warrior #1 dismounts.  His eyes fall on young Sarah.  He back at his friend with a toothless grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can eat if you want.  I'm going to start with her. Warrior #1 walks towards Sarah who clings to her Mother. Farmer stands in the path of the Warrior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Warrior #1 backhands the Farmer across the face, sending falling to the ground.  Sarah tries to run but the Warrio grabs her.  He lifts her over his shoulder and carries he inside the barn, closing the door behind them.  We HEAR S SCREAM.  A beat.  Suddenly, the doors of the barn crash o the Warrior flies out of the barn and lands on his back. Macleod steps out of the barn, his Samurai in hand.  Warr #2, still mounted on his horse grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It appears this farmer has a temper. Warrior #1 staggers to his feet.  He removes his sword an stares angrily at Macleod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This farmer is dead. Warrior #1 lunges at Macleod who casually sidesteps his a and slices his sword across the Warriors chest.  The Warr GASPS, then falls to the ground dead. Warrior #2 cannot believe what he has seen.  Anger fills face.  He reaches to the side of his saddle and lifts a C BOW.  Macleod changes his grip on the sword and holds it spear.  He THROWS it at the Warrior at the same time he F the cross bow.  The sword flies into the Warrior's stomac Blood flows from his mouth.  A beat.  He falls from the s dead. Macleod is standing, an ARROW dead-center in his chest. flows from the wound.  He slowly walks into the barn.  Th Farmer runs after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Farmer enters.  Macleod is on his knees, his face fil with pain.  He pulls the arrow from his chest and stands. farmer cannot believe what he has just seen.  He crosses himself. Outside, through the open barn doors we see Sarah and her mother running towards them.  The Farmer quickly closes t doors and bolts them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) This cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.  Do not ask me how.  I do not know.  I must leave, for if I stayed others would surely hear of this and worse than they will come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) I would like to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors opens and the Farmer comes outside.  He motions his wife and Sarah to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is crying as she enters with her Mother and Father. Macleod is laying on the ground, his head propped up unde mat of straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quick -- he has not much time. Tears flow from Sarah's eyes as she kneels next to Macleo She holds his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave us, Conner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) It's not for me to decide. He gently wipes her tears away with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't cry, wee one.  It's a better place I go to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Conner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye -- I know, Las -- and I have never loved anyone more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll no forget you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) And I you.  Go now.  Let me walk to heavens door alone. The Farmer ushers his wife and Sarah from the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Farmer sits on a cart pulled by an ox.  He stops and around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This should do. In the back of the cart Macleod lifts up a tarp and gets He looks down in the valley.  He can see the LIGHTS in th FARMHOUSE below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.  I will dig a grave and mark it with your name. The farmer's voice is distant.  He is still unable to gra what he has seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Macleod reaches up his hand.  The Farmer does not take it Macleod understands.  He starts to walk off into the nigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conner? Macleod turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not pretend to understand what I have seen this day.  I am a simple man.  Whatever you be -- demon or spirit -- I thank you for the life of my Sarah and I wish you God's peace. The Farmer turns the cart around, leaving Macleod alone, staring into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod is still staring out the window as the memories f back into the past.  He opens the book of poetry and sear through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) The forest is lovely.  Dark and deep -- but I have promises to keep -- and miles to go before I sleep. Another FLASH of LIGHTNING.  He looks out the window into night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) "Miles to go before I sleep"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WIND HOWLS through the valley.  Outside the crumbling of the STONE BUILDING (we saw in the opening sequence) ar several four wheel drive trucks and vans.  PROFESSOR PAUL DAJORSKI, is a typical academic in his fifties: beard, gl pipe, tweed jacket.  He walks across the field with a REP and CAMERAMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For years this site was thought to hold no archaeological value.  That is until a few weeks ago when some local boys discovered what appears to be a collapsed passageway that leads into a cavern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer until you expect to enter the main cavern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we're going to find out now. A STREAK OF LIGHTNING CUTS across the clear blue sky. Professor Dajorski looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to the lightning) I've never seen anything like that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just started a few hours ago. WORKERS exit the building pushing wheelbarrows filled wit and dirt.  The Professor enters the stone building, follo the Reporter and his team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside groups of VOLUNTEERS attend to various functions. Professor Dajorski walks through the room.  The Camera Cr follows. WE MOVE WITH THEM as they walk down a long tunnel that le into the mountain. JENNIFER HILLMAN an attractive woman in her late twenties stands next to a TECHNICIAN.  They each watch the screen bright green light oscillates up and down.  She looks up Dakorski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electro magnetic soundings indicate we've only got a few inches of rock left before we reach the main chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea how big the cavern is on the other side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you hoping to find inside? The question strikes Jennifer as odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are from the British museum, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- we're from Strange facts and mysteries.  It's a syndicated show out of..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dajorski) Paul.  I thought we agreed.  No press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little.  Who knows what we're going to find in there.  It could be a huge excavation.  A little friendly PR never hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the film crew from the British Museum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've had a little car trouble. I'm afraid they won't be here until after dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we shouldn't break into the cavern until tomorrow morning.  This could be a very important find.  I want it documented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is quiet.  Trucks and Vans are parked near the struct

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUARD sits in a fold-out chair at the entrance to the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELECTRIC LIGHTS are set up at intervals along the tunnel. HEAR a SCRATCHING SOUND.  A beat.  The SOUND grows LOUDER of the huge rocks blocking the tunnel begins to move.  It forward slowly, then falls to the ground with a THUD.  Th now a hole in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUARD hears the SOUND.  He turns around and looks dow tunnel, then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard reaches the end.  He sees there are now several on the ground and the hole in the wall is now even bigger Guard slowly removes a FLASH LIGHT and moves towards the He shines the light inside and looks in.  A beat -- then, suddenly and hand reaches out, grabbing the Guard and pul him in through the hole.  A beat.  ALL IS QUIET. Kilvara steps out through the hole holding his sword.  He shields his eyes from the light and moves towards the exi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilvara steps outside.  He takes a deep breath, filling h lungs with the cool night air.  A moment later he is join the two Horsemen.  Kilvara closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you feel it?  There is another one among us.  It has not ended?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now? Kilvara opens his eyes and slowly looks at the Horseman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is as it was before. Kilvara raises his sword -- swings in at the Horseman -- severs his head from his body.  The other Horseman looks horror.  He backs up slowly, then runs off.  Kilvara prep himself to receive the power.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A Brilliant GREEN LIGHT pierces the darkness, lighting th front of the Stone Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod bolts up in bed.  He stares out the window sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeenth century England. Macleod rides his horse along a road blanketed by dense f on each side.  Suddenly, he stops his horse as a premonit fills him.  He looks around.  A horse is tethered to a tr the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day. The VOICE comes from above.  Macleod looks up.  Sitting o branch of a tree that extents over the road is THOMAS CAVANAUGH.  He is a large, robust MAN in his fifties dres thick sheepskins.  He drops from the tree landing before Macleod.  Macleod slowly reaches for his Samurai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have no need for that, Highlander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since we hardly know each other, I'm sure you'll understand if I hold one to it for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caution shows wisdom. Cavenaugh notes the Samurai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that weapon.  It belonged to Juan Romeriz.  He's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He was my brother.  He died at anothers hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We too are brothers, Macleod.  In fact, you have more family than you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas Cavenaugh.  I am a teacher of sorts.  Like Romeriz I help those newly acquainted with our life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I learned my fill from Romeriz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed you did.  And now it is time for you to pass on to others what you learned from him. Cavenaugh walks over his horse and mounts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they can take my head? Cavenaugh rides over to Macleod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your head is not important, Highlander.  What is important is the prize.  It must go to one who would not misuse it.  Ride with me.  Come and meet your family. Cavenaugh's horse begins to walk away.  Macleod stares af him, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Church stands alone in a valley, it's stone walls col from time and neglect.  Fog carpets the ground.  HORSES a CARTS are in front of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only three of the four stone walls are standing.  A large section of the roof is gone.  Inside are about thirty MEN WARRIORS, fierce and hard-looking.  They stand before wha was the altar and listen as Cavenaugh speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've called this gathering on holy ground so that each man might take comfort in knowing he is protected inside the confines of these walls. None of us, good or evil would dare raise a hand against the other in God's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If God protects us so, why has he cursed us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God's purpose for us is unclear, save that he has given us a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gift?  You call never growing old - - watching friends and loved ones die a gift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not profess to know what is in God's mind.  He has chosen us.  We are his warriors through time.  The final Gathering is still far away but the prize must be captured by a man who is pure of heart.  Those of us who would use the prize for goodly purpose must band together against those who would use it for evil. In the back of the room, standing alone is Macleod.  His are on the altar, but his mind seems far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod walks with Cavanaugh, weaving through the crowd o and horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prize?  So much blood so that in the end the one that remains will be mortal again.  So much pain so that the winner can grow old and have children.  The prize hardly seems worth the cost of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be more to the prize than that.  Power will come with it -- and it must be used for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The days of magic are ending.  The world is changing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye -- yet one such as I who has wandered this world for nearly nine centuries can remember back to other days of change.  Days of Robin of the Hood and Arthur Pendragon.  They were real enough once, but they drifted into men's dreams and became legend - - as we shall do one day. Macleod stops at his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grow weary of the fight. Macleod mounts his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot run from your destiny, Conner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps -- but if I must face it, let it find me, for I shall search for it no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Dajorski walks quickly to the Stone Building. area is surprisingly empty.  Jennifer walks over to meet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?  Where is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're holding the workers down below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone broke into the cavern last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  How? Jennifer begins to walk.  Dajorski follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not quite sure.  The Guard was knocked out. Dajorski is concerned.  Jennifer waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fine.  He swears he never left his post for a moment.  He heard a noise and when he went back to look they were already inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could they get by him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Jennifer stops.  A few feet away lies the torso of the ho covered by a blanket.  Beside him, covered with a jacket head.  Dajorski looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) We found him this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) What's that next to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His head.  Someone cut it off. Dajorski shivers at the thought of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this. Jennifer lifts the cloth.  Dajorski isn't pleased with th sight, but he immediately sees what she is referring to. bends down and examines the dead man's clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible.  The cloth -- the buttons -- it looks to be mid sixteen hundreds.  It's a remarkable duplication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it is a duplication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this? Jennifer lifts the sword.  Dajorski examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same period -- and exceptionally well preserved.  Jennifer, what's going on here? Jennifer look back at the stone building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good question.  That's a very good question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod comes out of the elevator.  He walks over to Rach the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out for a while. Rachel opens a drawer and removes a set of keys.  She han them to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kept it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Macleod smiles and kisses her on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tarp is pulled off of a 1958 convertible PORSCHE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PORSCHE roars up the driveway and out onto the street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filtered light flows through stain glass windows.  Macleo alone in the pew.  He stares at the altar, his mind deep thought.  A PRIEST walks down the aisle -- stops -- studi for a moment, then sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look troubled my son. Macleod's mouth hints at a grin from the Priest's understatement.  He does not look at the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we feel better if we talk about the things that bother us.  How long has it been since your last confession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distantly) A long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think confession will help me, father. Macleod stands and prepares to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redemption is one of God's gifts. Macleod looks at the Priest sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God's gifts?  You mean like, life, having children, growing old, dying and heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are gifts I can never have. Macleod walks down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are too young to be so bitter. Macleod stops.  He turns back and looks at the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) I'm older than I look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desolate area of the RIVER.  Abandoned WAREHOUSES line waterfront.  His PORSCHE is parked in the b.g.  Macleod l against the railing, staring out over the water.  A beat. Suddenly, Macleod stiffens, his gaze lifts off the water. premonition fills him.  He turns around, knowing what he find behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other Horseman approaches.  He holds his broad sword side. Macleod holds his hand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  We don't have to do this. The Horseman lunges at Macleod.  He raises the sword and it down quickly.  Macleod moves quickly to his side.  The miss him by inches as it smashes into the railing, slicin through the metal. Macleod stares into the Horseman's eyes -- they are cold, savage.  He knows there is not point in talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Macleod opens his rain coat and slowly removes the ancien Samurai sword.  He expertly twirls the sword as he raises over his head and holds it in a fighting stance.  A beat. men lock eyes.  The Horseman attacks. Blades cross.  Sparks fly.  The men move across the quay towards the warehouse. The Horseman thrusts his sword.  Macleod steps to the sid slices the blade of the Samurai across the Horseman's fac deep gash appears, blood flows down his cheek.  The Horse touches the wound, looks at the blood on his finger, then tastes it.  He grins and attacks. The Horseman whirls his sword, swinging furiously at Macl Blow after powerful blow pounds against the samurai.  Mac is backed up against the railing.  The swords cross and remained locked -- each man pushing against the other in of strength. The Horseman knees Macleod in the groin.  Macleod doubles The Horseman brings the butt of his sword down hard betwe Macleod's shoulder blades.  Macleod falls to his knees, dropping his sword.  The Horseman lifts the Samurai and t it behind him.  Macleod struggles to shake the pain from body as the Horseman raises the sword above Macleod's nec As he brings it down, Macleod lunges forward, hurling his into the Horseman and picking him.  Macleod's runs across quay carrying the Horseman on his shoulder.  The Horseman raises his sword above his head.  Macleod heads towards o the large windows of the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH!  Glass shatters as Macleod and the Horseman break through the window.  Carcasses of BEEF hang from hooks on curving S-HAPED processing line.  Slowly the two warriors to their feet.  The Horseman's sword is a few feet behind He stands and walks to it.  Macleod looks around the room looking for something -- anything -- that might be used a weapon. The Horseman attacks, swinging his sword wildly.  Macleod the racks of beef, using them as a shield.  The Horseman' blade slices through the meat.  Macleod back up, grabs an side of beef and pushes it into the Horseman.  The impact knocks the Horseman to the ground.  His sword slides acro floor.  The Horseman gets up and walks over to his sword. Macleod grabs one of the MEAT HOOKS and hurls it towards Horseman's back.  The Horseman has just about reached the when the Hook spears him between the shoulder blades. Macleod pushes a RED BUTTON.  The processing line begins move -- the hook lifts, picking the Horseman off the grou The Horseman tries desperately to reach the hook, but he cannot.  Macleod picks up the sword and readies himself. Horseman heads back towards Macleod .  In one fluid motio Macleod cuts off his head -- leaving the rope intact.  Th headless body continues to swing across the room. A beat.  Macleod readies himself for what he knows his co Sparks of green light begin to pulse out from the Horsema headless body. Macleod's body stiffens as a jolt of power fills him.  Ov LIGHT FIXTURES CRACKLE as the LIGHT BULBS begin to glow. ENGINE of an old fork lift comes to life.  A RADIO turns filling the room with MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one the WINDOWS EXPLODE, raining a shower of glass the dock -- and then -- SILENCE. An exhausted-looking Macleod staggers out of the building searches through the darkness until he finds his sword, t runs off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeenth century England. Macleod rides along the shores of the river.  Cavanaugh r beside him, singing and old FOLD SONG loudly.  His voice clearly annoys Macleod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a beautiful day.  I am merely enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you enjoy it quietly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you always this pleasant? (Macleod doesn't answer) You know what you're problem is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? Cavanaugh forces a grin.  He stops his horse.  Macleod st beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life.  You've stopped living it.  You look, but you do not see.  You listen but, you do not hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?  What else do you hear right now? Macleod listens for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Cavanaugh closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you not hear the wind in the trees?  The songs of the birds.  The horses breath? (beat) There is a whole world around you. Alive.  Living.  Feel it -- become part of it.  Live your life, Highlander.  It's going to be a long one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is what bothers me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  You don't care about life anymore. Macleod shrugs his shoulders, indicating he doesn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not. In an instant Cavanaugh draws his sword and swings it at Macleod's neck.  Just as quickly Macleod removes his Samu and blocks the attack.  A beat.  Cavanaugh grins, then lo his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You protect yourself well for a man who doesn't care if he lives or dies. Cavanaugh moves his horse forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back at Macleod) Fear not, my friend -- we're all going to die.  It's just going to take us longer, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small country inn.  A fire roars in the fireplace.  Mac sits at a table, staring into the flames.  Cavanaugh join carrying to tankards of ale.  A beat.  Cavanaugh does not interrupt Macleod's thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: England.  There is nothing for me here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you think you will find in another land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's worth the journey. Macleod holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For being a friend when I needed one. I hope our paths cross again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As friends -- always as friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cannot write our destiny, Macleod. In the end it could be you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a thought that doesn't please me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it came down to it what would you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know.  I pray that I shall never have to raise my sword against one that I call friend. Cavanaugh raises his tankard.  Macleod joins him.  They t there tankards together and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several BLACK AND WHITE POLICE CARS are in front of the building.  An unmarked car drives up and BEDSOE the cop f Highlander one gets out.  He is older, heavier and now a Lieutenant.  He walks towards the entrance of the warehou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE OFFICERS and members of the FORENSIC TEAM search t the rubble for clues.  The headless corpse of the Horsema still hanging from the meat hook in between several slabs beef.  Bedsoe enters at stares at the gruesome sight.  A DETECTIVE GRELEY, a sloppy-looking man in his thirties jo him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caretaker found him this morning. He's got no I.D. on him -- we'll have to run his prints. Bedsoe looks around the room.  The scene is all too famil him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, whaddaya think, Lieutenant,

dialogues.speaker: U.S.D.A
dialogues.text: Greley grins.  Bedsoe looks at him askance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find a sword?  An old sword?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Yeah -- how'd you know that? Bedsoe ignores the question.  He looks away, his mind dee thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to himself) He's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old building set among warehouses and abandoned buildi In the b.g. looms the modern high-rises of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room, filled with tables that are piled high with artifacts.  Professor Dajorski enters, hangs up his jacke walks across the room.  Jennifer is asleep at a workbench head resting on the surface.  Dajorski stares at her for moment, then gently wakes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stayed here again last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was working on the cataloging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer, there is more to life than work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?  Then why don't you go out? Meet someone.  Make a life for yourself instead of hiding away in the past?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having some people over tonight for dinner -- I'd like you come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) We'll see. Dajorski knows her well enough to know when to stop pushi He places a copy of the morning paper in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a lok at this. Jennifer lifts the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) The headless corpse of a man was found early this morning in a meat packing warehouse near the river. Police say the unidentified body was dressed in what appears to be a costume from the seventeenth century... Jennifer lowers the paper and looks at Dajorski with conf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old building with several large PILLARS running from f to ceiling.  MR. PARKER, a distinguished looking man in h forties stands at counter.  He finishes filling out a dep slip, then endorses the back of a check.  Parker looks at line, puts the check in his BRIEFCASE, then walks towards bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Parker walking into the bathroom.  The POV slowly head towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walking along the stall, looking under them to see if the occupied.  We come to one and see a pair of shoes.  A bea The POV rises, as if the person is straightening up.  A b Suddenly the door is kicked open, revealing Mr. Parker si on the toilet.  He looks up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilvara is standing at the entrance of the stall with a g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TELLER, a bored middle-aged woman looks up routinely Parker walks to her window with his check in one hand, hi briefcase in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon... (looks at name plate) ... Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to deposit this in your account?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  The money, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This check is for sixteen thousand dollars.  That's a lot of cash to be carrying around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take care of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  It's going to take a few minutes.  I have to call and verify the funds. We hold on Mr. Parker who is becoming a little anxious. The Teller is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- I'll hold. Mr. Parker taps his fingers on the counter.  The CLOCK on wall behind him reads: 1:10 The Teller hangs up the phone and walks back to her stati Mr, Parker looks pale, beads of sweat dot his forehead. CLOCK on the wall now reads: 1:22.  The Teller takes out several stacks of ONE HUNDRED DOLLAR BILLS.  She starts t count them.  Mr. Parker scoops them into his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay -- I trust you. Mr. Parker walks away.  His face sweats more, his body stiffens.  He draws the attention of a GUARD.  Mr. Parker behind one of the PILLARS as he heads for the exit.  When see him again he looks different.  He passes behind anoth and again when we see him he appears different.  From pil pillar his shape changes until when he passes from behind last one he is now Kilvara. The Guard cannot believe what he has seen -- or what he t he has seen.  He weaves in an out of the pillars looking any sign of Mr. Parker.  There is none.  He rushes up to Kilvara who is still holding the BRIEFCASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment, Sir. Kilvara stops.  He turns around slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you come with me please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think not. The Guard moves closer.  Kilvara slowly reaches his free under his jacket.  The Guard instantly removes his revolv aims it at Kilvara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze! Kilvara stares at the gun with amusement.  In a flash his his drawn.  He moves towards the Guard.  The Guard FIRES. first three shots hit Kilvara in the chest -- his light c shirt splatters with blood.  The shots drive him backward not down.  He staggers forward.  The Guard FIRES three mo shots.  Kilvara falls to the ground on his back. The Bank breaks into Chaos.  CUSTOMERS dive to the ground Guard slowly moves over Kilvara and kicks the sword away. leans over to take a pulse.  Kilvara's eyes open.  He gra Guard by the throat and lifts him off the ground and he s Kilvara pushes him against the wall and stares angrily in eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed off) That hurt. In the b.g. we HEAR POLICE SIRENS.  Kilvara knows he has time.  He lets go of the Guard, picks up his sword and ru from the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator opens and Macleod steps out carrying a DUFFL Rachel is at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have come back here.  It was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a mistake for someone to go to the ones who love them when they're in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- when their troubles can harm them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why won't you ever let anyone help you? Macleod puts his bag down near the counter.  He touches Rachel's face lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because no one can. We HEAR the BELLS on the front door as someone opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Nash. Macleod turns around.  Bedsoe is standing at the door wit DETECTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Bedsoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting him) Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Bedsoe walks towards him.  Rachel pushes the duffel bag b the counter with her foot, hiding it from Bedsoe's view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess what we found this morning? Macleod shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) A body -- with it's head cut off. Sound familiar? Macleod doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) When did you get back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I figured.  Well, I have a little home coming present for you. Bedsoe pulls out his HANDCUFFS and dangles them before Ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've been waiting seven years for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod and Bedsoe sit on opposite side of a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you last night around nine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already told you.  I took a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me again.  Where'd you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Central Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't it scare you walk through the park at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I don't scare easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been for the last seven years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Brenda? A sadness falls across Macleod's face.  Bedsoe has seen t look before -- he knows what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Macleod doesn't answer the question.  His personal life i open for discusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a good woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't bring me here to talk about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Bedsoe picks up an 8x10 PHOTOGRAPH of the HEADLESS CORPSE the meat packing warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I brought you here to talk about him. Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't look familiar -- but then he'd probably be easier to identity with his head. Macleod and Bedsoe lock eyes.  A beat.  There is a KNOCK two-way mirror.  Bedsoe gets up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedsoe walks over to CAPTAIN NEWSOME.  We can Macleod thr the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the middle of an interrogation, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interrogation's over, Bedsoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut him loose.  The D.A. says you ain't got shit on this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand.  About seven years ago we found the body of a guy named Vasilnic in Jersey.  A week later in the parking lot of Madison Square Garden we found Iman Fasil. Three days after that Luman Castageer was found in an alley.  The fourth body we've never been able to identify.  All four men died from decapitation.  Nash was our primary suspect -- but he disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's circumstantial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Chrissake!  Gimme a break.  The guy disappears for seven years and as soon as he comes back it starts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see your point, Bedsoe, but I have to look at this from the law's point of view.  There's something missing here.  It's something I'm sure you've come across many times in your career.  It's called evidence. (beat) Get me a murder weapon with his fingerprints on it.  Find me an eye witness.  Dig up a motive.  Until then we don't have a case against him. The Captain walks away.  Bedsoe is furious.  He looks at Macleod who is staring at him through the mirror as if he exactly what is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod walks towards the exit with Bedsoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't over Nash.  It's just beginning. Jennifer is sitting on a chair.  She gets up and walks ov Bedsoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Bedsoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now.  I'm busy. Macleod's attention is focused on Jennifer.  It's as if h knows her but can't quite place her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macleod) I'm gonna nail you, Nash.  That's a promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that it? Bedsoe steps in.  His face is inches from Macleod's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm telling you right now, the next person's head that comes off is gonna be yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Lieutenant, you're really frightening me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controlled anger) Get outta here. Macleod walks out the door.  He stops and looks back at Jennifer again, then leaves.  Bedsoe NODS to a DETECTIVE starts to walk after him.  Macleod appears in the doorway with a grin.  The Detective stops and tries to act noncha Macleod leans towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Detective) I'm going to Jimmy's Bar on West sixty seventh for drink.  See you there. Macleod grins at Bedsoe, then leaves.  Bedsoe stares afte hatefully.  Jennifer approaches him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) What?  Who are you?  What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Jennifer Hillman.  I'm an archaeologist.  I read in the paper about the murder yesterday and I thought I should come talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to me about what? Jennifer opens an ENVELOPE and removes a PHOTO of the cor Horseman #1 at the Scotland site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About this. Bedsoe looks at the PHOTO, then back at Jennifer.  He ush into his office and closes the door.  Through the GLASS P we see them talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedsoe is there with Jennifer.  A the headless CORPSE of Horseman #2 is laying on one of the steel tables.  The ME EXAMINER, a short, fat man in his forties is eating a don

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it wasn't easy but I finally determined the cause of death. Bedsoe doesn't find any humor is this.  Jennifer goes ove the counter and looks through the personal affects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Besides not having a head he's in perfect health.  No cavities. No broken bones.  Have you found out who he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's nobody.  The police, the F.B.I, Interpol -- nobody has record of this guy.  It's like he was never born. Jennifer is examining the Horseman's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what Scotland Yard said about the person we found at the site. Bedsoe walks over to Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They appear to be authentic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are people walking around New York with swords, dressed in mid evil clothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, technically it's not mid evil - - it's Renaissance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever -- it's old clothing, right? This is some weird shit. Detective Greley enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Lieutenant, the boys in robbery have something I think you should look at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tape from the surveillance camera at the First National Bank.  It was robbed this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  I want to make sure that I understand what you're telling me, Greley.  A crime was committed in New York City?  That is news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy had a sword and was dressed like this guy. Bedsoe's interest is peaked.  He looks at Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not all, Lieutenant.  Wait until you see the tape.  It's unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jennifer) I'd like you to see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON TELEVISION SCREEN.  We see Kilvara walking towar GUARD with his sword.  The GUARD fires at him.  Kilvara m towards him again.  The Guard FIRES again.  Kilvara falls the ground. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Bedsoe, Jennifer, Greley an several other Detectives looking at the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch this part. On the Television we see Kilvara reach up and grab the Gu then stand up unharmed.  Bedsoe cannot believe what he ha seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell.  What is this?  A joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No joke, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the guy we saw in the beginning -- what's his name...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker.  We found him knocked out in the can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he was knocked out in the can how could be walking across the lobby? The robbery detective shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I don't have answers for this. I just brought you down here because of the sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to believe that this guy got shot in the chest six times at point blank range and just got up and walked out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can believe what you want.  You saw the tape. Bedsoe walks out of the room.  Jennifer follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer catches up to Bedsoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see this.  Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) That guy you were talking to upstairs -- Nash.  You think he knows what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me worry about Nash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod walks along a gravel path.  He stops and looks be him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the Detective trying his best not to be seen. Macleod continues to walk.  He stops at a large POND.  CH play, sailing miniature SAILING SHIPS.  Macleod stares at ships -- his mind drifts.

dialogues.speaker: MINITURE SAILING SHIP
dialogues.text: It moves over the choppy water, bobbing up and down behin waves.  It disappears behind a wall of water -- when it reappears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real Eighteenth century sailing ship, churning the roug water of the Atlantic. Macleod stands on the deck, staring out at the horizon. A of water shoots over the side drenching him.  He closes h eyes and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to fall over you damn fool. Macleod turns around to find a rather pale Cavanaugh stan behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Thomas.  What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't think I'd let you go off by yourself, did you? Macleod embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking a wee bit green, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sea and I don't agree with each other.  Where we off to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly feeling sicker) How long is the voyage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long.  We should arrive in the morning. (amused) Are you going to be alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?  Of course. The ship rolls up over a wave.  Cavanaugh's face cringes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord have mercy. Cavanaugh bends over the rail dropping out of FRAME.  Mac grins as he watches him.  Slowly his grins fades -- the s of Cavanaugh's illness affects him.  Macleod holds his st his cheeks bulge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. Macleod bends over the rail and out of FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Horse-drawn COACH arrives.  TRAVELERS disembark.  Among is Macleod and Cavanaugh.  A small, street-wise man named GASTON approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) Excuse me gentlemen.  My name is Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macleod) What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English) Ah, you are English.  I speak English.  My name is Gaston.  For a small fee I would gladly be your guide. Macleod and Cavanaugh look at each and decide why not. Cavanaugh tosses up and coin which Gaston eagerly grabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need food and lodging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to worry, Monsieur.  My Uncle owns a very reputable inn. Gaston takes Cavanaugh's bag and carries it.  He attempts take Macleod's, but Macleod will not let go of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was journey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  I'd recommend it for anyone who wants to lose weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedsoe is watching the TAPE of the bank robbery on a smal television.  Detective Greley enters holding a PHOTOGRAPH Kilvara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is, Lieutenant.  We blew it up off the tape.  Every cop in the city has a copy of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good -- also, give it to the papers and TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, the guys in robbery are gonna get kind of upset.  We're stepping on their toes of this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a homicide, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ties in with Nash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have any proof of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need proof.  I know it.  Send it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer sits at one of the microfilm machine scanning ov newspaper articles.  She stops at one that reads:  ANTIQU DEALER ARRESTED IN CONNECTION WITH HEADLESS CORPSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer looks through the WHITE PAGES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) Russell Nash Antiques.  Hudson street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod walks towards the entrance of the shop.  As he re the door Jennifer steps out of the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Nash? Macleod turns towards her.  His face betrays nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Jennifer Hillman.  I was at the police station earlier today--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering if I could talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm an archaeologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we have anything to talk about, Miss Hillman. Macleod enters the store.  Jennifer follows after him determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod walks across the room.  Jennifer enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling after him) Not even headless corpses wearing seventeenth century clothing? Macleod turns around slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corpses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  We found another man outside a site we were working at in Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the highlands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lucky guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so -- but then, maybe you've can guess how a guy with a sword could rob the First national Bank this afternoon -- and get shot six times in the chest by the guard and still get up and walk out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was wearing a bullet proof vest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullet proof vests don't bleed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs his shoulder) You got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I feel that you know what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the type of person who takes advice, Miss Hillman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's good advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is.  Go home.  Stay out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  What's going on? Macleod shows a hint of frustration that she isn't going take his advice.  Macleod starts to walks away.  Jennifer his arm.  Macleod turns around  and pulls her hand away. Suddenly his expression changes as he stares at her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her finger is a distinctive RING.  It is very old intr gold patterns carved in gold and set in ivory. Macleod is shocked.  He slowly raises her hand up before face and looks her in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get this ring? Jennifer is more than a little frightened by Macleod inte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mine.  It's been in my family for years.  It belonged to my great, great, great grandmother. Macleod stares at the ring again -- his mind drifts away moment, then he looks at Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Miss Hillman. Macleod walks towards the elevator. A beat.  Jennifer gat her composure -- in spite of his intensity there is somet that interests her about Macleod.  Macleod steps in the elevator and looks back at her.  He says nothing.  The el doors close.  Jennifer stares after him, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Macleod walks down the hall Rachel opens her bedroom d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard voices downstairs.  Is everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing I can do.  I'll wait. One way or another soon it will all be over soon. Macleod feigns a grin for Rachel's sake.  He leans in a k her on the forehead, then continues down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly as we remember it from Highlander one.  Macleod s the couch, next to the aquarium.  His eyes drift up a sto wall at the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Macleod eyes drifting up the wall.  PULL BACK TO REVEA are now at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteenth century France. An elegant room.  Aristocrats, dressed in lavish clothing mingle and dance.  Macleod and Cavanaugh stand off to the They are well dressed with white, powered wigs.  Cavanaug clearly uncomfortable with his dress and surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living.  Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tugs at his clothing) You may be living -- but this suit is killing me. Something catches Macleod's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room, standing with a group of pompous-looking is ISABELLE TOUREZ a beautiful woman in her early twentie She looks remarkably like Jennifer.  Her gaze falls on Ma she smiles shyly. Cavanaugh follows Macleod's stare.  He knows when trouble coming -- and this is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's beautiful. Macleod starts to walk over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To ask her to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the King's cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she should be an excellent dancer. Macleod walks across the room, his eyes on Isabelle.  She forward as he approaches, leaving the group of MEN behind Macleod smiles and bows, then offers her his hand.  She t it and they walk out onto the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod and Isabelle lay on a blanket in a green meadow. Macleod seems preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conner? Macleod looks at her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you go when your mind drifts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The past?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it you never talk to me about Scotland -- your life there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's the past -- and things that are in the past are best left there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will I be part of your past or your future? Macleod does not answer.  He looks away sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macleod enters.  He is happy, playful.  He sees Cavanaugh sitting near the window.  He appears distracted.  Macleod notices his behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong? Cavanaugh turns towards him slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What worries you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Macleod knows where this conversation is going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been seeing her for over a month now.  Have you learned nothing from the past?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've learned that a man can only go so along living alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you do this for yourself?  What about her? (beat) You cannot not have a relationship, Macleod.  You've told me of your wife, Heather, and how you loved her. Romeriz warned you then, but you would not listen.  You watched her grow old and die -- and there was nothing you could do. A sadness falls over Macleod as he remembers.  Cavanaugh over to him and puts his arm on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
